Library Modules

The inference package library modules implement tools that are largely self-contained. They fall into three categories: statistical tools, signal models, and utility modules.

Statistical Tools

The following items are each separate modules containing functions and classes implementing the described tools.

count
Tools for analyzing integer count data. Currently the main module is on_off, implementing Bayesian inference for signals estimated from joint analysis of on-source and off-source data (i.e., a Poisson rate with an uncertain, constant background).
drxn
Tools for analyzing directional data, including quantifying direction uncertainties with Fisher distributions, and Bayesian assessment of directional coincidences.
gauss
Tools for analyzing data consisting of samples of a function measured with additive Gaussian (normally distributed) noise. It includes implementations of the Bretthorst algorithm for modeling data as a linear superposition of nonlinear model terms.
montecarlo
Objects implementing sampling methods useful for Monte Carlo calculations. The population module implements sampling from a (possibly weighted) population, with or without replacement; Sampford's method for "probability proportional to size" sampling is implemented here. The pwlinear module implements sampling a distribution defined by a probability density on a grid, interpolating linearly.

In addition, the sandbox contains the following modules that will soon be migrated into the released package.

asurv
A Python interface to Eric Feigelson's asurv package.
bha
"Bayesian Harmonic Analysis," an implementation of the Bretthorst algorithm optimized for periodic models (sums of harmonic sinusoids) for uniformly sampled time series data.
odiag
Various routines for Markov Chain Monte Carlo output diagnostics.
point
Methods for Poisson point process models; currently the main module under development implements the Gregory-Loredo algorithm for detecting periodic signals in arrival time series. A module implementing the Rayleigh test is also under development.
regress
A Python interface to Matthew Bershady's package implementing a variety of methods for linear regression when both variables are subject to errors, and there is intrinsic scatter in the underlying true bivariate distribution.

Signal Models

The signals module contains the following modules:

  • kepler — Tools for calculating Keplerian orbital motion, including a fast Kepler equation solver.
  • cosmology (currently in the developer release) — Fast calculation of common quantities in cosmology, such as luminosity distance, look-back times, universe age, volume element (all vs. redshift), etc..

Utility Modules

The following modules implement computational algorithms that are not intrinsically statistical, but that arise often in statistical computation.

deriv
Numerical calculation of the observed Fisher information matrix via Ridder extrapolation of finite differences.
grid
Modules for calculating quantities over grids. grid1d maintains a function evaluated on a 1-D grid, with capability to automatically refine the grid near peaks, and to calculate integrals over the grid (useful for time series analysis). hpd contains objects that will take 1-D or 2-D grids of log probability density values, and calculate boundaries of highest posterior density regions (useful for reporting Bayesian HPD credible regions).
integrate
Modules implementing quadrature and cubature (multidimensional numerical integration) algorithms useful for statistical computation with models arising in astronomy and other physical sciences. These include Python interfaces to Alan Genz's well-known adapt and cuhre adaptive cubature algorithms, implementations of several 2-D cubature rules from Ronald Cools's Encyclopaedia of Cubature Formulas, and quadrature rules adapted for handling integrands with power-law behavior (currently in the developer release).

In addition, the utils module contains a variety of basic numerical, input/output, and plotting "helper" functions, and the rng module which supports saving and restoring the state of the numpy random number generator.
